application.ref: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Assessment of Peri-Articular Implant Fitting Based on Statistical Finite Element Modeling .=
S. Bonaretti1, N. Reimers2, M. Reyes1, A. Nikitsin1, A. Joensson2, L.-P. Nolte1, P. Büchler1 .=
1 ARTORG Center for Biomedical Engineering Research, University of Bern, Bern, Switzerland 2 Stryker Osteosynthesis, Kiel, Germany .=
Computational Biomechanics for Medicine III MICCAI 2008 Workshop, September 10 2008.=
— Statistical Shape Model — Fracture Creation and Propagation — Bone-Implant Fitting — Finite Element Analysis .=
How to make an implant “fit” a majority of people? .=
> Current implant design is based on limited knowledge about the target anatomy .=
> Existing possibilities: — Anthropomorphic data from the literature (incomplete information) — Cadaver experiments (fail to capture variability across individuals) .=
> There is no good model about the range of variability of bone shape (and bone quality) in a given target population.=
Statistical Fracture Bone-Implant Finite Element Shape Models Creation Fitting Analysis .=
— Statistical Shape Model — Fracture Creation and Propagation — Bone-Implant Fitting — Finite Element Analysis .=
> CT collection of different population: 43 Caucasian left tibias: 23 males, 20 females 47 Asian left tibias: 28 males, 19 females .=
> Principal Component Analysis: new instances for each population .=
— Statistical Shape Model — Fracture Creation and Propagation — Bone-Implant Fitting — Finite Element Analysis .=
— Statistical Shape Model — Fracture Creation and Propagation — Bone-Implant Fitting — Finite Element Model Analysis .=
> Both bone and implant represented like meshes: .=
> Iterative Closest Point Algorithm: argminå ei implant ei = dist(pi,CP(pi )) .=
> Closest points are iteratively found on the target shape and a new rigid transformation is computed:.=
> Constrained Iterative Closest Point: argminåwi ei outside .=
inside K e if inside K (Ntotal -Ninside)i i , i > "iÎVinside å ei .=
— Statistical Shape Model — Fracture Creation and Propagation — Bone-Implant Fitting — Finite Element Analysis .=
> Bone and implant are meshed with 10-node tetrahedrons .=
> Screws modeled with beam elements — Circular section (radius 3.3mm) — Connection to the bone made with .=
> Mechanical properties: — Bone: E=6.95ρ1.49 — Implant: titanium properties .=
> Boundary conditions: — 2 times body weight — Distal extremity fixed — Bone/bone contacts.=
— Statistical Shape Model — Fracture Creation and Propagation — Bone-Implant Fitting .=
> Finite Element Analysis > Results > Discussion and Future Works.=
> No statistical differences between Asian and Caucasian.=
> Higher stresses for Asian than for Caucasian (p < 0.05).=
— Statistical Shape Model — Fracture Creation and Propagation — Bone-Implant Fitting — Finite Element Analysis .=
> Assessment of orthopaedic implant fitting combining Statistical Shape Models and Finite Element Analysis .=
> Non-rigid-registration-based procedure: — No landmark definition — Method for fracture propagation .=
> The biomechanical analysis highlights details that the shape fitting can not detect (statistical significance).=
— Adding statistical modeled intensity to the bones .=
